awd_titl_txt: Differential Geometry and Analysis for Elastic Rigidity and Flexibility
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator pursues several directions of research in mathematics that are of both analytical and geometrical nature and could have applications in nonlinear elasticity and materials science. The questions under study lie at the interface of differential geometry and analysis. This project aims to establish new connections between these disciplines that will be of interest to mathematicians as well as members of the solid mechanics and materials science community. The work aims to advance materials science, particularly regarding the behavior of pre-strained elastic bodies or growing tissues. It is anticipated that the results will have many potential applications, from constructing shape-forming gels to detecting cancerous tumors. 

This research project further explores the flexibility vs. rigidity dichotomy, particularly in the context of isometric immersions and solutions to Monge-Ampere equations of low regularity. The rigidity and flexibility of solutions to various classes of partial differential equations in geometry and continuum physics has been a longstanding mathematical problem. Recent developments in fluid dynamics have interested mathematicians and materials scientists in analytical and geometrical aspects of these problems. Meanwhile, a rigorous understanding of nonlinear elastic phenomena (including elastic rigidity and flexibility) requires a deep engagement with mathematical disciplines such as differential geometry and nonlinear analysis. The principal investigator plans to use techniques including convex integration, the theory of nonlinear partial differential equations, geometric function theory, and geometric measure theory to tackle these questions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
The award supported the study of the rigidity and flexibility of solutions to various classes of partial differential equations (PDEs)  in geometry and continuum physics. Recent developments in fluid dynamics has arisen the interest of the community of mathematicians and materials scientists in analytical and geometrical aspects of the flexibility and rigidity problems. Meanwhile, a rigorous understanding of nonlinear elastic phenomena (including elastic rigidity and flexibility) requires a deep engagement with mathematical disciplines such as differential geometry and nonlinear analysis. Certain classes of weakly regular deformations, namely solutions to isometric immersion system of equations and solutions to Monge-Amp?re equations of low regularity, arising in the above contexts,  were the subject of this project.  Techniques from many fields of modern mathematics, -such as nonlinear analysis, theory of nonlinear PDEs, geometric function theory and geometric measure theory, were used to tackle the suggested problems.  The award  also promoted interdisciplinary interactions and the research was carried on in close connection with the applied mathematics, materials science and the biomechanics communities. 

 

The award has helped to advance the mathematical knowledge regarding the questions of rigidity and flexibility and the behavior of nonlinear elastic plates. Among the major findings of the award have been a set of new rigidity results regarding weakly regular isometric immersions of flat and curved  surfaces in the Euclidean space, and derivation of a new reinforced plate model from the 3 dimensional nonlinear elasticity. The nonlinearity of equations, in this context (as it is in others)  is one of the major sources of technical difficulties on the way to a complete mathematical understanding of the solutions. These difficulties are reflected in the complexity of various phenomena in materials science, such as turbulence in fluid mechanics or morphogenesis of elastic bodies.  The above results have opened the way to fresh considerations regarding regularization methods for understanding nonlinear equations.  Another side achievement of the project has been the suggestion and analysis of new nonlinearly geometric elastic plate models of deformations with fractional regularity. Finally, the project has lead to  new insights regarding the distributional Jacobian determinant, of which establishing some previously unknown features became a necessary step in advancing the project. 

 

Articles based on the results obtained by the PI and his collaborators were peer reviewed and will be published   in renowned  international scientific journals.  Participation in mathematical conferences and interaction with colleagues from other disciplines for dissemination of the results  were among another activities undertaken by the PI.   The PI was an invited speaker in many research institutes and universities and participated as organizer or invited speaker in  international conferences. The PI engaged in presenting short courses in order to disseminate the results and to encourage participation of young researchers towards achieving the longterm goals of the project beyond the official duration of the award. 

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Mohammad Reza Pakzad
